query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato, 2 quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco 3 che da neun sentiero era segnato.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Nessus had not yet arrived on the other side, 2 when we set out through a forest 3 that was marked by no path.
**Cornish:**
1 Nessa veu dos ha bos dhe’n tu arall, 2 pan wosa ni ow settya drefen coedh 3 na veu merkys war nen fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti 8 quelle fiere selvagge che ’n odio hanno 9 tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti.
query.result:
**English:**
7 There are no such rough thickets nor such dense 8 wild beasts that hate 9 the cultivated places between Cecina and Corneto.
**Cornish:**
7 Nyns eus kleudh na gemma na kemmys 8 an bestes gwyls eus yn kas haval 9 ynter Cecina ha Corneto an leow treus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Quivi le brutte Arpie lor nidi fanno, 11 che cacciar de le Strofade i Troiani 12 con tristo annunzio di futuro danno.
query.result: **English:**10 There the foul Harpies make their nests, 11 who drove the Trojans from the Strophades 12 with sad tidings of future harm.**Cornish:**10 Enotho Arpyow gwrello aga nidi, 11 a wrug an Trojanow a'n Ynysiow Strofad 12 gans kelmys nowodhow a-dhia dammaj a dheuth.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Ali hanno late, e colli e visi umani, 14 piè con artigli, e pennuto ’l gran ventre; 15 fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 E ’l buon maestro «Prima che più entre, 17 sappi che se’ nel secondo girone», 18 mi cominciò a dire, «e sarai mentre
19 che tu verrai ne l’orribil sabbione.
query.result:
**English:**16 And the good master said, "Before you go any further, 17 know that you are in the second circle", 18 he began to tell me, "and you will be there until
19 you come to the horrible sand."**Cornish:**16 Ha'n mester da "A-rag termyn nag esa moy, 17 godhvos bos yn-mes an nessa kynsa", 18 a dhallathsa dha'm, "ha bos ena bys
19 bys vyth dheuth dhe'n garrek erghus."**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
20 Però riguarda ben; sì vederai 21 cose che torrien fede al mio sermone».
22 Io sentia d’ogne parte trarre guai 23 e non vedea persona che ’l facesse; 24 per ch’io tutto smarrito m’arrestai.
query.result:
**English:**
20 But look carefully; you will see 21 things that would make my words seem unbelievable».
22 I heard cries of pain from every side, 23 but I could see no one who was making them; 24 so I stopped, completely bewildered.
**Cornish:**
20 Mes gwel yn dha; yth gwely bys 21 traow a wra dhegredhes vyth preder.
22 Yth klevon gow gowhes an gwelas 23 neb an wra ow th'aga; 24 rag wov yth omdhiskwedhes yth sevas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Cred’ ïo ch’ei credette ch’io credesse 26 che tante voci uscisser, tra quei bronchi, 27 da gente che per noi si nascondesse.
query.result:
**English:**
25 I believe that he believed that I believed 26 that so many voices came forth, among those branches, 27 from people who were hiding from us.
**Cornish:**
25 Kredaf vy ef a greas vy greas 26 henna liesow a dheuth, ynter an keun, 27 a bobel a wra golow dheworthyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Però disse ’l maestro: «Se tu tronchi 29 qualche fraschetta d’una d’este piante, 30 li pensier c’hai si faran tutti monchi».
query.result:
**English:**
28 But the master said: “If you break off 29 a small branch from one of these plants, 30 the thoughts that you have will all be shattered.”
**Cornish:**
28 Mes a leveris an mester: “Mar thu a dhevnyth 29 un pren vyghan a unn a’n plansow ma, 30 an menowgh a wra genvys vy a vydh torrys.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Allor porsi la mano un poco avante 32 e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno; 33 e ’l tronco suo gridò: «Perché mi schiante?».
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then I stretched out my hand a little forward 32 and picked a small branch from a large thorn bush; 33 and its trunk cried out: “Why do you tear me apart?”
**Cornish:**
31 An gwreydh vy’m dhorn vy dheudhenn dheworth 32 ha mos vy un pren vyghan a unn prun meur; 33 ha’y goolen a leveris: “Perag vy’m torra?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Da che fatto fu poi di sangue bruno, 35 ricominciò a dir: «Perché mi scerpi? 36 non hai tu spirto di pietade alcuno?
37 Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi: 38 ben dovrebb’ esser la tua man più pia, 39 se state fossimo anime di serpi».
query.result:
**English:**
34 When it was then made red with blood, 35 it began to say again: “Why do you tear me apart? 36 Do you have no spirit of pity at all?
37 We were men, and now we are made into shrubs: 38 your hand should indeed be more merciful, 39 even if we had been the souls of serpents.”
**Cornish:**
34 Pan wrughaf o gwydh goch, 35 a leveris arta: “Perag vy’m torra? 36 Na’th eus spyrys a drugaredh?”
37 Dynnyon o ni, ha nyns yw ni mes 38 dy dhorn dhefya moy es, 39 mar ni veu ni enevalow.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Come d’un stizzo verde ch’arso sia 41 da l’un de’ capi, che da l’altro geme 42 e cigola per vento che va via,
43 sì de la scheggia rotta usciva insieme 44 parole e sangue; ond’ io lasciai la cima 45 cadere, e stetti come l’uom che teme.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Like a green stick that is burnt 41 at one end, which at the other end groans 42 and hisses because of the wind that escapes,
43 so from the broken branch there came forth at the same time 44 words and blood; whereupon I let the tip 45 fall, and stood like a man who is afraid.
**Cornish:**
40 Vel un pren gwyrdh ow tos, 41 ow tos yn unn a’y bennow, ow kewina 42 ha kewsel drefen an gwyns a dremena,
43 hemma an pren a dhrehedh, yn keffrys, 44 geryow ha gwydh; rag henna vy a leas 45 an benn dhe woles, ha sevel avel den a wra ofn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 «S’elli avesse potuto creder prima», 47 rispuose ’l savio mio, «anima lesa, 48 ciò c’ha veduto pur con la mia rima,
49 non averebbe in te la man distesa; 50 ma la cosa incredibile mi fece 51 indurlo ad ovra ch’a me stesso pesa.
query.result:
**English:**
46 “If he could have believed beforehand,” 47 my wise guide replied, “wounded soul, 48 what he has just seen with my rhyme,
49 he would not have stretched out his hand towards you; 50 but the incredible thing made me 51 persuade him to an action that weighs on me.”
**Cornish:**
46 “Mar a veu gallos kredis kyns,” 47 a leveris vy mester fur, “enavalow gweythys, 48 henna a welas gans vy ryma,
49 na veu ef estynnys y dhorn dheugh; 50 mes an drav anvoskredadow a wrug 51 vy dhemedhes dhe ober a wra poos dhe’m.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Ma dilli chi tu fosti, sì che ’n vece 53 d’alcun’ ammenda tua fama rinfreschi 54 nel mondo sù, dove tornar li lece».
query.result:
**English:**
52 But tell me who you were, so that in place 53 of some amends your fame may be refreshed 54 in the world above, where it is permitted to return.**Cornish:**
52 Mesdywedhes pyth vyth os, rag y'n le 53 rag nebes amendys vyth klodho porres 54 yn bys ughella, lemmyn ytho porres dyllo.**

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 E ’l tronco: «Sì col dolce dir m’adeschi, 56 ch’i’ non posso tacere; e voi non gravi 57 perch’ ïo un poco a ragionar m’inveschi.
query.result:
**English:**
55 And the trunk: "Yes, with your sweet speech you entice me, 56 that I cannot be silent; and do not think it burdensome 57 if I indulge myself a little in speaking."
**Cornish:**
55 Ha'n tronk: "Ia, gans dha lavar dhoalek owth tynnerghys, 56 henna na wra vy dhelergh; ha na wrasoth 57 mar ke dhelergh un byghan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Io son colui che tenni ambo le chiavi 59 del cor di Federigo, e che le volsi, 60 serrando e diserrando, sì soavi,
61 che dal secreto suo quasi ogn’ uom tolsi; 62 fede portai al glorïoso offizio, 63 tanto ch’i’ ne perde’ li sonni e ’ polsi.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I am the one who held both keys 59 to Frederick’s heart, and who turned them, 60 locking and unlocking, so gently,
61 that I took almost everyone into his secrets; 62 I was faithful to my glorious office, 63 so much so that I lost sleep and strength because of it.
**Cornish:**
58 My yw an neb a dhegevas an dhew gevren 59 a galon Fydrik, ha’gas ow toskas, 60 ow serrya ha’gas ow diserrya, mor serth,
61 hemma ow kemeras pubonan dhe bys vyth dhe’y gellys; 62 ow porthas feyth dhe’m offis glorius, 63 bys vyth ow kollevas ankow ha’m nerth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 La meretrice che mai da l’ospizio 65 di Cesare non torse li occhi putti, 66 morte comune e de le corti vizio,
67 infiammò contra me li animi tutti; 68 e li ’nfiammati infiammar sì Augusto, 69 che ’ lieti onor tornaro in tristi lutti.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The harlot who never turned her wanton eyes 65 away from Caesar’s court, 66 the common death and vice of courts,
67 inflamed all hearts against me; 68 and she inflamed Augustus so much 69 that my joyful honors turned to sorrowful mourning.
**Cornish:**
64 An vreten diworth, neb a drehevas byth 65 y golon a lys Cesare, y lagadow put, 66 ankow kemmyn ha’gas vyth a lysow an lys,
67 a enefas pubonan an enep a’m aga, 68 ha’gas an enefys a enefas Awgust mor, 69 hemma an enorow lowen a dheuth ha’gas kolgow trist.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 L’animo mio, per disdegnoso gusto, 71 credendo col morir fuggir disdegno, 72 ingiusto fece me contra me giusto.
query.result:
**English:**
70 My soul, out of disdainful pride, 71 believing that by dying I would escape disdain, 72 unjustly made me just against myself.
**Cornish:**
70 An enep vy, rag an growt disdegnus, 71 ow kredis dre worfen ow toskas disdegn, 72 a wrug anvos vy dhe’m just a’m aga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Per le nove radici d’esto legno 74 vi giuro che già mai non ruppi fede 75 al mio segnor, che fu d’onor sì degno.
query.result:
**English:**
73 By the nine roots of this tree 74 I swear to you that I never broke faith 75 with my lord, who was so worthy of honor.
**Cornish:**
73 Dre naw golon an prenn ma 74 owth leveris dedh vyth byth na wrug ow feyth 75 dhe’m argluydh vy, o veu mor enor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 E se di voi alcun nel mondo riede, 77 conforti la memoria mia, che giace 78 ancor del colpo che ’nvidia le diede».
query.result:
**English:**
76 And if any of you return to the world, 77 comfort my memory, which lies 78 still suffering from the blow that envy dealt it.
**Cornish:**
76 Ha’gas neb a’yugh vy dhe dhro dhe’n bys, 77 a gonsolya an kov a vy, neb a wra 78 bythkweth dhe’n kolp hemma an gonol a ro’s.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Un poco attese, e poi «Da ch’el si tace», 80 disse ’l poeta a me, «non perder l’ora; 81 ma parla, e chiedi a lui, se più ti piace».
query.result:
**English:**
79 He waited a little, and then, "Since he is silent," 80 the poet said to me, "do not waste the time; 81 but speak, and ask him, if it pleases you more."
**Cornish:**
79 Ev eth omsettya, hagena, "Rag ev a wra, 80 a leveris an bardh dhymm, "na golla an eur; 81 mes lever, ha gofyn dhodho, mar pleg dhe wel."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Ond’ ïo a lui: «Domandal tu ancora 83 di quel che credi ch’a me satisfaccia; 84 ch’i’ non potrei, tanta pietà m’accora».
query.result:
**English:**
82 Then I said to him: "Ask him again 83 about what you think would satisfy me; 84 for I cannot speak, so much pity overwhelms me."
**Cornish:**
82 Ha henna dhymm: "Gofyn dhodho arta 83 a-dro dhe gresi a wra sodhek; 84 rag ny wodhvyn vy, kemmys an trues a'm gorra."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Perciò ricominciò: «Se l’om ti faccia 86 liberamente ciò che ’l tuo dir priega, 87 spirito incarcerato, ancor ti piaccia
88 di dirne come l’anima si lega 89 in questi nocchi; e dinne, se tu puoi, 90 s’alcuna mai di tai membra si spiega».
query.result:
**English:**
85 Therefore he began again: "If a man 86 freely does for you what your speech entreats, 87 imprisoned spirit, may it still please you
88 to tell us how the soul is bound 89 in these knots; and tell us, if you can, 90 if any ever extricates itself from such members."
**Cornish:**
85 Rag henna a dhallathas: "Mar wra dynner 86 yn frank an peth a wra dhe lever gwedhes, 87 speris y'n karhar, ha bos dhe wel
88 rag leverel dhyn, pena wra an enef 89 yn an kodhow ma; ha leverel dhyn, mar gallos, 90 mar wra unn bythkweth a-dro dhe'n esel ma."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Allor soffiò il tronco forte, e poi 92 si convertì quel vento in cotal voce: 93 «Brievemente sarà risposto a voi.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Then the trunk sighed heavily, and then 92 that wind became a voice, saying: 93 "Briefly shall you be answered.
**Cornish:**
91 An henna a sowenas an tronk yn krev, ha henna 92 a wra an gwyns na enef ma yn lever ma: 93 "Yn berr a wra gwellhes dhyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Quando si parte l’anima feroce 95 dal corpo ond’ ella stessa s’è disvelta, 96 Minòs la manda a la settima foce.
query.result:
**English:**
94 When the fierce soul departs 95 from the body from which it has torn itself, 96 Minos sends it to the seventh abyss.**Cornish:**
94 Panvrea an eneval an eneval kalonnek 95 a'gan korf pan wre dha dhisplegya, 96 Minos a wra dhe'n seythves avon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Cade in la selva, e non l’è parte scelta; 98 ma là dove fortuna la balestra, 99 quivi germoglia come gran di spelta.
query.result:
**English:**
97 It falls into the forest, and there is no choice of place for it; 98 but wherever fortune hurls it, 99 there it germinates like a grain of spelt.**Cornish:**
97 A wra yn y'n gwydh, ha nyns yw rann dhewisys; 98 mes le may hyns fordhon a wra'n balestredh, 99 eno hy a wra'n ow tyvi avel gron spelta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Surge in vermena e in pianta silvestra: 101 l’Arpie, pascendo poi de le sue foglie, 102 fanno dolore, e al dolor fenestra.
query.result:
**English:**
100 It shoots up into a sapling and a wild plant: 101 the Harpies, feeding then on its leaves, 102 cause pain, and make a window for the pain.**Cornish:**
100 Hy a wra'n ow tyvi avel gron spelta: 101 an Harpyes, ow poswa orth y foel, 102 a wra gweles dolur, ha fenestr dhe'n dolur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Come l’altre verrem per nostre spoglie, 104 ma non però ch’alcuna sen rivesta, 105 ché non è giusto aver ciò ch’om si toglie.
query.result:
**English:**
103 As the others will come for our spoils, 104 but not so that anyone may clothe themselves in them, 105 for it is not right to have what one takes away.
**Cornish:**
103 Vel dell re beu a dheuth drefen agan despoylys, 104 mes na veur henna bos re beu dhe viska, 105 rag na veur gwir bos re beu dhe gemeres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Qui le strascineremo, e per la mesta 107 selva saranno i nostri corpi appesi, 108 ciascuno al prun de l’ombra sua molesta».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Here we will drag them, and through the sad 107 forest our bodies will be hung, 108 each one on the thorn of his own troublesome shade.
**Cornish:**
106 Ama yma y fynnons ni, ha dre’n goel 107 koedh a vydh agan korfow gwlaset, 108 pub on dhe bren a’y skwydh anken.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Noi eravamo ancora al tronco attesi, 110 credendo ch’altro ne volesse dire, 111 quando noi fummo d’un romor sorpresi,
112 similemente a colui che venire 113 sente ’l porco e la caccia a la sua posta, 114 ch’ode le bestie, e le frasche stormire.
query.result:
**English:**
109 We were still waiting at the trunk, 110 believing that he wanted to say something else, 111 when we were surprised by a noise,
112 similar to that which one hears when 113 the boar and the hunt come to its lair, 114 and one hears the beasts and the rustling of the branches.
**Cornish:**
109 Ni o nessa dhe’n tronk, ow tos, 110 ow kredis ow fynnons ef a leveris nebes, 111 pan veu ni surpresys gans un sôn,
112 ow kompareb dhe’n neb a glew 113 an vorh ha’n helgh dhe’y let, 114 ow klev an bestys, ha’n brysow ow stormya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Ed ecco due da la sinistra costa, 116 nudi e graffiati, fuggendo sì forte, 117 che de la selva rompieno ogne rosta.
query.result:
**English:**
115 And behold, two from the left side, 116 naked and scratched, fleeing so fast 117 that they broke every branch of the forest.
**Cornish:**
115 Ha, weles, dew a’n kos dhe’n klew, 116 noeth ha skrabys, ow fugi ow fleghes, 117 bys ow torras pub brys a’n koedh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Quel dinanzi: «Or accorri, accorri, morte!». 119 E l’altro, cui pareva tardar troppo, 120 gridava: «Lano, sì non furo accorte
121 le gambe tue a le giostre dal Toppo!».
query.result:
**English:**
118 The one in front: “Now run, run, death!”. 119 And the other, who seemed to be lagging behind too much, 120 shouted: “Lano, your legs were not so nimble
121 at the jousts by the Toppo!”.
**Cornish:**
118 An neb a-rag: “Weles, skor, skor, ankow!”. 119 Ha’n neb aral, ow semedh dhe vos ow tarde, 120 ow klewas: “Lano, na veu dhe’gas mor sprek
121 dhe’gas gesys dhe’n Toppo!”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
122 E poi che forse li fallia la lena, 123 di sé e d’un cespuglio fece un groppo.
124 Di rietro a loro era la selva piena 125 di nere cagne, bramose e correnti 126 come veltri ch’uscisser di catena.
query.result:
**English:**
122 And then, perhaps because he was running out of breath, 123 he made a bundle of himself and a bush.
124 Behind them the forest was full 125 of black hounds, eager and running 126 like greyhounds unleashed from a chain.
**Cornish:**
122 Ha wosa heb falli analen, 123 ef a wrug groop a-dhi ha brys.
124 Wosa ow tos o nessa an koedh leun 125 a goon howsys, ow fleghes ha ow redya 126 kepar kelgis ow tos ow toskynna a-dhi chayn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 In quel che s’appiattò miser li denti, 128 e quel dilaceraro a brano a brano; 129 poi sen portar quelle membra dolenti.
query.result:
**English:**
127 They sank their teeth into the one who had hidden himself, 128 and tore him limb from limb; 129 then they carried away his suffering limbs.
**Cornish:**
127 Yn neb a-dhi ow tos ow kudha’y dens, 128 ha’y a-dhi ow torras a-dhi brys a-dhi brys; 129 wosa ow porthas an membrys dolensi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Presemi allor la mia scorta per mano, 131 e menommi al cespuglio che piangea 132 per le rotture sanguinenti in vano.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Then my escort took me by the hand, 131 and led me to the bush that was weeping 132 in vain for its bloody wounds.
**Cornish:**
130 Presa’m ena dhe’n prysner gans an dorn, 131 ha’m porthas dhe’n brys ow piwas 132 rag an torras gweliow gans gwag yn van.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 «O Iacopo», dicea, «da Santo Andrea, 134 che t’è giovato di me fare schermo? 135 che colpa ho io de la tua vita rea?».
query.result:
**English:**
133 “O Jacopo,” it said, “from Santo Andrea, 134 what good did it do you to make me a shield? 135 What fault of mine is it that your life was wicked?”.
**Cornish:**
133 “O Yagos,” ow leveris, “a-dhi Sen Andras, 134 pyth o veur gwel dhe wul dhe’m gwari skerm? 135 Pyth yw an koweth dhe’m bew dhe’gas byw vyth vyth?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Quando ’l maestro fu sovr’ esso fermo, 137 disse: «Chi fosti, che per tante punte 138 soffi con sangue doloroso sermo?».
query.result:
**English:**
136 When the master stood still over it, 137 he said: “Who were you, that through so many wounds 138 you breathe out a speech of blood and pain?”.
**Cornish:**
136 Pan veu an mester ow tos ow tos dhe’y ferm, 137 ow leveris: “Pyth o vos, pyth o sofras gans ken poynt, 138 serm gans gwag ha gow gweliow?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Ed elli a noi: «O anime che giunte 140 siete a veder lo strazio disonesto 141 c’ha le mie fronde sì da me disgiunte,
142 raccoglietele al piè del tristo cesto.
query.result:
**English:**
139 And he said to us: "O souls who have come 140 to see the shameful devastation 141 that has so separated my branches from me,
142 gather them at the foot of the sad bush."
**Cornish:**
139 Ha henna dhe'n: "O enewegow pyth eus 140 eus dhe weles an strazhy anvonest 141 eus eus ow fronjow kemmys da'm dysjunys,
142 rekollet ow dhe'n traes an trist kest."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
143 I’ fui de la città che nel Batista 144 mutò ’l primo padrone; ond’ ei per questo
145 sempre con l’arte sua la farà trista; 146 e se non fosse che ’n sul passo d’Arno 147 rimane ancor di lui alcuna vista,
148 que’ cittadin che poi la rifondarno 149 sovra ’l cener che d’Attila rimase, 150 avrebber fatto lavorare indarno.
query.result:
**English:**
143 I was from the city that, by the Baptist, 144 changed its first patron; for which reason
145 he will always make it sad with his art; 146 and if it were not that on the banks of the Arno 147 there still remains some trace of him,
148 those citizens who later rebuilt it 149 on the ashes that remained from Attila, 150 would have labored in vain.
**Cornish:**
143 Y'th o an cita ma, dre'n Batyst 144 a dhyskynjas an kynsa patron; rag orth an keus
145 bythkweth a wra gena trist gans y arta; 146 ha na vijhe nebes orth pass Arnow 147 a wra ges owth owth henna nebes gwelys,
148 henna dusysi a wra'gas owth avel 149 orth an losow a wra ges owth Attila, 150 a wra gwres owth oberi heb dowr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
151 Io fei gibetto a me de le mie case».
query.result:
**English:**
151 I made myself a gibbet from my own houses.
**Cornish:**
151 Yma gwres gibet dhe'm a'm chi.
